headline: Marathon Petroleum Plans to Spin Off Gas Stations, May Shake Up Leaders
summary: Marathon Petroleum is preparing to spin off its gas-station chain and considering shaking up its executive leadership to appease activist shareholders, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: GM and Toyota Back Trump Administration on Emissions Rules
summary: GM and Toyota are siding with the Trump administration as environmental groups challenge its proposed rollback of California emissions rules.

headline: Employees Ask Facebook to Reverse Policy on Political-Ad Fact-Checking
summary: A group of Facebook employees asked the company to reverse its policy of exempting political candidates’ ads from its own fact-checking program, calling the controversial rules a betrayal of the social-media giant’s values.

headline: Former Alstom Executive Challenges Reach of U.S. Foreign Bribery Law
summary: A former Alstom executive mounted a direct challenge to the long reach of the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act on Monday, the first day of a trial in a case that has raised legal questions about who is subject to the foreign bribery law.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Oct. 29, 2019

headline: Photos: Flames Rage as Winds Whip California
summary: Powerful winds fanned wildfires in California over the weekend, prompting the evacuation of tens of thousands of people. Utility PG&E cut power to an estimated 2.4 million people in an effort to prevent more fires.

headline: State Court Prohibits Use of North Carolina Congressional Map for 2020 Elections
summary: A panel of North Carolina judges blocked the state from using a Republican-drawn congressional map for the 2020 elections, stepping in after the U.S. Supreme Court declined to referee the matter.

headline: Google’s Ad Business Hums Along Though Profit Falls
summary: Google’s internet empire hauled in more money from online advertising than ever in the third quarter. But rising costs and poor results from some equity investments weighed on profit, and shares in its parent Alphabet dropped in after-hours trading.

headline: Trump Administration to Allow Thousands of Salvadorans to Remain in U.S. for Extra Year
summary: The Trump administration will allow tens of thousands of Salvadorans living in the U.S. under temporary protected status to stay an additional year, as the two countries continue negotiations over immigration.

headline: Juul to Cut About 500 Jobs
summary: Juul plans to cut roughly 500 jobs by the end of the year, reversing the e-cigarette maker’s rapid staff growth as the company braces for a proposed ban on flavors that make up more than 80% of its U.S. sales.

headline: California vs. the Constitution
summary: Sacramento can’t run its own foreign policy on climate change.

headline: Pelosi Concedes on Inquiry Vote
summary: A House impeachment resolution is the start of political accountability.

headline: The Fed Needs Trust, Not Tactics
summary: Interest-rate cuts won’t hold off the next downturn. The central bank must assure markets with a plan.

headline: ‘Vicksburg’ Review: Breaking the Confederacy
summary: “The Yankees . . . are worse than the Goth and Vandals of the middle ages,” wrote one Confederate soldier. The feeling was mutual.

headline: Tiffany Acquisition Would Be LVMH’s Most Challenging Yet
summary: In targeting Tiffany, French billionaire Bernard Arnault, faces rejuvenating a company whose strategy and management have been in upheaval.

headline: Lukewarm Bond Yields Belie Mayors’ Climate Alarm
summary: If politicians believe what they say on the campaign trail, why don’t their cities disclose it to borrowers?

headline: The Military Shouldn’t Shave Its Numbers
summary: Allowing beards could help bolster the ranks, and at no cost too.

headline: Trump’s Unfairness Advantage
summary: Pelosi realizes Democrats’ trampling of impeachment norms helps Trump.

headline: A Battle Won in the War on Terror
summary: Killing Baghdadi won’t ‘fix’ the Middle East, but ISIS’ failure is a crucial victory.

headline: Big Four Audit Firms Sell Less Nonaudit Work to U.K. Audit Clients
summary: Big Four audit and accounting firms in the U.K. are selling less nonaudit work to their audit clients, a finding that comes as some lawmakers are recommending firms separate their audit and consulting businesses to avoid conflicts of interest.

headline: Former President Tries to Turn the Tables on Powerful Bolivian Leader
summary: The politician leading the opposition against Bolivian President Evo Morales was forced to resign as president in the face of protests led by Mr. Morales in 2005. Now Carlos Mesa is attempting to use similar street tactics and international pressure to force the president to face him in a December runoff.

headline: T-Mobile Beats Rivals in Adding Phone Subscribers
summary: T-Mobile attracted a higher number of lucrative cellphone subscribers in the third quarter than Verizon and AT&T combined even as the fate of its Sprint deal remained in limbo.

headline: Grubhub’s Profit Falls as Delivery Competition Accelerates
summary: The delivery company plans to spend more on promotions to counter rivals including DoorDash and Postmates.

headline: Man Pleads Guilty to All 23 Counts in Capital Gazette Massacre
summary: A Maryland man pleaded guilty in the slayings of five staffers at an Annapolis newspaper, and a jury is expected to hear testimony within weeks about whether he wasn’t responsible by reason of insanity.

headline: U.S. Recovered Valuable Intelligence in Baghdadi Raid
summary: Defense officials and Pentagon leaders wouldn’t detail the intelligence recovered on Saturday, but said it consisted of data-storage devices and other files that will add to the understanding of Islamic State.

headline: Google’s Spending Is Back in Season
summary: Rising costs at parent Alphabet overwhelm its growth story.

headline: New York City Councilman Andy King Suspended Over Harassment Allegations
summary: The New York City Council voted to suspend Councilman Andy King from his seat for 30 days over allegations he violated its anti-harassment policy, intimidated staff members and misused city dollars for a staff retreat in the U.S. Virgin Islands.

headline: Beyond Meat Books First Profit as Competition Mounts
summary: The company is doubling down on marketing the nutritional value and environmentally friendly production of its meat alternatives in the face of growing competition to sell plant-based burgers.

summary: Virgin Galactic made its trading debut on the New York Stock Exchange, giving public investors their first chance to buy a piece of the space-tourism company founded by Richard Branson.

summary: The bar was unusually high for the company’s quarterly results.

headline: Robert Evans, Producer of ‘Chinatown,’ Dies at 89

headline: Patent Office Seeks Help From AI
summary: The U.S. Patent and Trademark Office is expanding its use of artificial intelligence to tackle steadily growing patent applications, including an influx of AI-related filings.

headline: Tina Turner Musical Is Off to a Strong Start on Broadway
summary: A new biographical Broadway musical about Tina Turner is poised to become a big hit, with strong sales in its first few weeks.

headline: Spotify CFO, Architect of Direct Listing, to Retire
summary: Barry McCarthy will retire as Spotify’s finance chief, leaving the role in which he oversaw the company’s unusual direct stock listing and guided the streaming giant through its first year and a half on the public market.

headline: Trump Campaign Looks to Capitalize on Baghdadi Raid
summary: President Trump and his re-election campaign are moving swiftly to capitalize on the death of Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, casting the risky mission as a sign of strong leadership while seizing the moment for fundraising appeals.

summary: Spotify Technology’s new finance chief faces a challenging task allocating the media streaming service’s capital amid strong competition from Apple, Amazon.com and other technology companies.

headline: Trump Attacks Chicago Police Superintendent Over Crime Rate
summary: President Trump bemoanedand criticized the city’s police superintendent, who boycotted Mr. Trump’s remarks to a gathering of police chiefs.

headline: FCC Targets China’s Huawei and ZTE
summary: The Federal Communications Commission is moving to place another restraint on the U.S. business of Huawei Technologies and ZTE by banning U.S. companies receiving federal subsidies from purchasing the Chinese firms’ equipment.

headline: PG&E Pain Spreads to Utility’s Bonds

headline: Stocks’ Return to Records Led by the Usual Suspects: Large Tech
summary: Stocks rose broadly higher Monday, but it is a handful of big technology shares that have led the S&P 500 to its latest record.

headline: Gold Investors Prep for Packed Week of Data
summary: The 2019 rally in gold appears to be at a crossroads in the final week of October, increasing attention on how the haven metal performs during a packed slate of economic data points.

headline: A Positive Sign for Luxury New York Real Estate: A $55.5 Million Condo Sale
summary: The sale at 220 Central Park South is viewed as a shot in the arm to the struggling ultra high-end market.

summary: U.S. government-bond yields rose Monday, extending their recent climb as traders prepared for a busy week highlighted by a Federal Reserve meeting and several top-tier economic-data releases.

headline: New York City Had 114,000 Homeless Students Last Year

headline: ‘The Bakersfield Sound: Country Music Capital of the West 1940-1974’ Review: Evolution of a Sound
summary: A massive set from Bear Family takes a deep dive into this Western musical outpost.

headline: Far-Right Gunman Attacks Mosque in France, Injuring Two

headline: Grudge Match: House vs. Executive Privilege
summary: Nancy Pelosi has no more power than I do to launch an “impeachment inquiry” unless she does so as the speaker of the House of Representatives. She can’t speak for the House without a vote, which she hasn’t called.

headline: Competition Will Improve Rating Standards
summary: The North American rating oligopoly retains a more than 85% share of the European market a decade after the financial crisis.

headline: Where an Attorney General Works After Leaving Office

headline: California Pols Have It Both Ways on High Gas Prices
summary: This is how socialism works, increase regulations until the private companies have to raise prices, then blame those companies for raising prices as the excuse to take them over or more regulations.

headline: Manulife, Alphabet Venture Launch Insurance Partnership for Diabetics

summary: Wind-driven wildfires and mandatory blackouts have become a new normal for Californians.

headline: Apple Bets on New $249 AirPods Pro Amid Weak iPhone Sales

headline: FCC Answers The Threat From Huawei

summary: The Fed’s shift from tightening in 2018 to easing in 2019 has made for easier financial conditions, yet it hardly seems like a fire has been lighted under the economy.

headline: Baseball’s Postseason Is Wild. But It Has Become Weirdly Predictable.

headline: Delaney’s Complaint: Democrats’ System Tilts Left
summary: John Delaney has toiled in the Democratic presidential primary, working on the assumption that there would be a place for a centrist not named Joe Biden. What he has found, he says, is a process that tilts toward candidates of the left, which, not surprisingly, is the direction the party has moved.

headline: Bitcoin and Chinese Tech Stocks Surge After Xi Jinping Touts Blockchain
summary: China’s president said the country should speed up research into the technology underpinning digital currencies, fueling a surge in related stocks and bitcoin, which briefly topped $10,000.

summary: The New York Fed added $76.583 billion in liquidity to financial markets by way of an overnight repurchase-agreement operation.

summary: The driver of a truck in which 39 people were found dead was charged with manslaughter, money laundering and conspiring to traffic people into the U.K., as investigators continued the wrenching task of identifying the victims, some of whom may have come from Vietnam.

summary: The outlook for coal miners in pro-Trump West Virginia is only getting dimmer, and the presidential race doesn’t seem to offer much chance of a turnaround.

summary: As HSBC posted a disappointing set of third-quarter results, the bank’s caretaker chief executive promised to deliver in February new targets and a plan to overhaul the business. That assumes he is still in charge.

summary: Wisconsin Democrats are planning a show of force ahead of the 2020 election in a state crucial to President Trump’s re-election bid that is showing signs of stress from his trade wars.

summary: Tiffany, AT&T, Walgreens Boots Alliance and Microsoft are some of the companies with share expected to trade actively in Monday’s session.

headline: ‘Why Is This Airplane Still Flying?’ The FAA Missteps That Kept Boeing’s MAX Aloft
summary: After the first crash in October 2018, an agency analysis showed a good chance the Lion Air malfunction would happen again. But the FAA followed Boeing’s lead on key aspects of the response, setting the stage for the second fatal crash months later.

summary: The Federal Reserve’s interest-rate cuts appear to be giving a lift to housing, autos and big-ticket items like appliances while delivering less of a boost to companies.

headline: House to Vote on a Road Map for Its Impeachment Inquiry
summary: The House plans to vote on a resolution laying out Democrats’ next steps in the impeachment inquiry into President Trump and move to a public phase of the investigation, the first significant vote since the probe began.

summary: Tens of thousands of residents evacuated as a fire spread swiftly through the city and utility companies planned another week of widespread blackouts with more strong, dangerous winds forecast.

summary: Chinese investors are pressing ahead in Silicon Valley, putting money into startups and venture-capital funds—moves that highlight the resilient relationship with American entrepreneurs amid broad U.S. efforts to limit foreign access to technology deals.

headline: IMF to Test Argentina’s New Leader
summary: President-elect Alberto Fernández, a populist, must reconcile his campaign- spending promises with the strict fiscal demands of the International Monetary Fund.

summary: AT&T struck a deal with Elliott Management, which had been pressuring the telecom giant to revamp its strategy, and said its chief executive will stay at the helm through next year. Quarterly profit and revenue fell.

summary: The U.S. airstrike further clouded the extremist group’s future after the death of its leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, in a U.S. military raid.

headline: Johnson Loses Bid for Early Election but Takes New Tack to Get One
summary: A British general election remains likely this year as a way to resolve the Brexit stalemate, even though lawmakers blocked a bid by Prime Minister Boris Johnson to schedule an early ballot.

headline: S&P 500 Rises to a Record
summary: The broad S&P 500 stock benchmark finished the day at a record for the first time in three months, kicking off a busy week featuring a flurry of corporate earnings, a Federal Reserve meeting and the October jobs report.

headline: Tough Questions, Anger Await Boeing CEO in Congress
summary: Boeing Chief Executive Dennis Muilenburg is set to tell lawmakers the company made mistakes that contributed to two fatal airplane crashes, as the aerospace giant struggles to regain public trust.

headline: White House Brings Lessons of Mueller to Impeachment Response
summary: Top White House officials have been urging a cautious approach to the escalating impeachment proceedings, under the belief that because President Trump withstood the Mueller investigation he can overcome the latest threat.

summary: Vaporizer products that contain vitamins and essential oils are largely escaping regulatory scrutiny, while being marketed on social media to young people as health products, and in some cases as ways to quit smoking.

summary: A year after the Khashoggi murder, Saudi Arabia is struggling to draw a diverse mix of global executives to its signature investment conference.

headline: Why Department Stores Are Becoming...Restaurants
summary: As retail sales continue to slow, stores like Nordstrom, Crate & Barrel and Tiffany & Co. are investing in eateries to give shoppers a new reason to come through their doors.

summary: As Sen. Elizabeth Warren develops her proposal for financing Medicare for All and reshaping how Americans pay for health care, she faces a complex set of challenges.

summary: The Spanish region's independence movement splits Catalans down the lines of age, class and language. Nowhere is that more evident than in two Barcelona neighborhoods.

summary: Lobbying expenditures by Facebook, Amazon and Apple are on pace to hit records this year. The companies are taking steps to present a positive message to Washington.

headline: Does Your Boss Have Your Back When a Loved One Dies?
summary: More companies are putting extra thought into their bereavement leave policies, one of the trickiest elements in any benefits package.

headline: Northern California Wildfire Grows Overnight, Forcing Evacuations
summary: California’s governor declared a state of emergency as a wildfire north of San Francisco burned nearly uncontrolled and millions of people were left without power as utilities tried to prevent more fires amid raging winds.
